description: abstract assemblage in browns, tans, grey, black and cream; raised rectangular box-like elements at center--some open, some "closed"; predominately horizontal and vertical layered elements of various colors and textures; one open rectangular box has thin paperlike elements in various layers; wavy black lines and small frenetic tic marks particularly concentrated on topmost closed rectangular box and at bottom center; metal envelope clasp at top left of center; received in a shadowbox with silver edging
medium: Oil, oil stick, ink, charcoal, tar, printed matter, cotton cloth, staples, Japanese paper, oil paper, watercolor paper, wrapping paper, thin paper, and cardboard on canvas
text: This work continues Ohtake Shinro’s practice of using collage to create forms that project off the canvas to occupy three-dimensional space, like a sculpture. Ohtake’s crusty collection of materials is full of tears, punctures, and other flaws, mimicking the messy, imperfect nature of memory. Layers of paper scraps create cracks and fault lines, suggesting that memory resembles Earth’s tectonic plates, whose shifting and sliding causes earthquakes and volcanoes. Lines drawn in with ballpoint pen may refer to the uneven flow of time.
title: Time Memory / Fault 11
